messages.speaker: user
messages.content: Hi, for apa citation am I allowed to do 'Jones (1998) argued that ...' without directly quoting the source?

messages.speaker: user
messages.content: for example. I am only paraphrasing the source and won't be directly lifting from it, is such a format acceptable or do i have to stick to the (Jones, 1998) at the end of the sentence?

messages.speaker: user
messages.content: not at the moment, thank you for your help!

messages.speaker: helpdesk
messages.content: May I clarify further what you mean by without directly quoting the source?

messages.speaker: helpdesk
messages.content: what you put in between the quotation marks looks good to me

messages.speaker: helpdesk
messages.content: okay first of all paraphrasing is always recommended over directly quoting

messages.speaker: helpdesk
messages.content: only quote when it is necessary and helps the argument in your writing.

messages.speaker: helpdesk
messages.content: Secondly, (Jones, 1998), Jones (1998) argued that... are both acceptable formats of APA in-text citation

messages.speaker: helpdesk
messages.content: Feel free to use them in the way you see fit. sometimes it helps to make the writing more fluent and readable

messages.speaker: helpdesk
messages.content: okay. do you have any other questions?
